Hydrogen, being a clean energy source, presents novel possibilities for the efficient exploitation of building energy. Nevertheless, the unpredictability in the production of renewable energy, the fluctuating demand from users, and the varying comfort needs within buildings provide substantial obstacles to the functioning of building energy systems. This work suggests an optimal technique for managing a comprehensive energy system based on hydrogen. The strategy takes into account the variability in energy sources and the need for user satisfaction. Firstly, a model of building integrated energy system (BIES) is created, which includes devices for utilizing hydrogen due to its adaptable qualities. Afterwards, the adaptable attributes of electrical, cooling, and heating loads within the building are carefully examined, resulting in the creation of a integrated demand response (IDR) model and a user-integrated comfort rating model. Moreover, a ladder-type carbon tax framework is implemented, employing robust optimization methods to tackle uncertainty in the production of renewable energy and demand. Finally, a model for optimizing the scheduling of energy system operation is formulated. A case analysis is performed utilizing a spacious office building located in the northern region as an instructive example. The findings indicate that the suggested approaches successfully control user involvement in demand response, decrease carbon emissions in the system, improve user energy comfort, and accomplish the economic, low-carbon, and comfortable functioning of BIES. upper limits of the i-th type of thermal equipment kW Q i max the output upper limits of the i-th type of cooling equipment kW 1 Introduction 1.1 Background The escalation of environmental pollution has made the strong development of clean energy and the reduction of carbon emissions crucial for attaining sustainable energy development [1]. Presently, construction energy consumption ranks equally with industrial and transportation energy consumption, establishing itself as one of the three primary energy-intensive sectors in China. Approximately 30% of the overall societal energy consumption is attributed to the usage of energy in buildings [2]. The annual increase in operational energy consumption and carbon emissions of buildings necessitates the urgent promotion of intelligent energy utilization in buildings. Around 40% of the demand response load in society is derived from the flexible and changeable loads found in structures, which offers significant potential [3]. Hydrogen is a low-carbon, clean, safe, and efficient secondary energy source that is known for its low pollution, high calorific value, and easy storage [4]. The incorporation of hydrogen into the entire building energy system is crucial for improving the adaptability of integrated energy systems (IES) and attaining “carbon peak” and “carbon neutrality” [5]. The introduction of hydrogen adds complexity to the energy coupling process in building energy systems, requiring further study of the energy flow. Predicting trends in renewable energy generation is problematic due to the presence of features such as imbalance, randomness, and volatility during its development [6]. Robust optimization (RO) is used to model the functioning of building energy systems under harsh situations by satisfying all constraints and seeking optimal solutions [7]. Robust optimization effectively reduces the influence of fluctuations in renewable energy generation on the optimization of complete building energy system operation. The growing emphasis on people-centric principles in green building has led to an increasing need for office and living settings that cater to user preferences [8]. Engaging users in demand response programs based on their energy consumption behavior can improve the internal comfort of buildings, offering residents or users a superior quality living and working environment. This necessitates a more rigorous optimization and scheduling process for building energy systems. By thoroughly evaluating the effects of uncertain energy sources and user comfort on optimizing the operation of building energy systems, and strategically coordinating user involvement in demand response, we can effectively improve the economic and residential comfort aspects of these systems. This will bring them in line with the design principles of environmentally friendly buildings. 1.2 Literature review Currently, scholars have conducted research on the comprehensive utilization of hydrogen energy, ladder-type carbon tax, demand response, and source-load uncertainty, as shown in Table 1 . However, their research on these factors is relatively one-sided, without considering the linkage effects between these optimization elements. For example, a stepped carbon tax will affect the comprehensive utilization of hydrogen energy, considering user comfort will affect the enthusiasm of users to participate in demand response, considering source load uncertainty will affect the adjustable load of the system, and indirectly affect user comfort. Therefore, it is necessary to comprehensively consider the impact of various optimization factors and output the optimal scheduling plan for BIES. The primary focus of research on the optimum operating of integrated energy systems with hydrogen lies in studying the steady-state energy flow relationships of hydrogen, coupled device modeling, and energy usage. Hussam et al. [9]investigated integrated supply models for solar power production, wind power generation, fuel cells, and energy storage, both in grid-connected and off-grid settings. The combination of grid-connected wind energy and photovoltaic solar energy integration can result in the most cost-effective energy usage and hydrogen production. Abdin et al. [10] evaluate the viability of hybrid energy systems that utilize renewable energy sources like solar and wind, in conjunction with hydrogen technology and solid-state lithium-ion batteries. The study focuses on maximizing the capacity configuration of renewable energy systems. Oskouei et al. [11] presents a stochastic security-constrained optimal power flow model that aims to optimize the power of Power-to-Hydrogen(P2H) units in regional networks dominated by renewable energy. The objective is to maximize the profits of the grid operator by increasing the sale of green hydrogen. Liu et al. [12] presents a coordinated operation strategy for a hybrid natural gas energy system that takes into account Power-to-Heat and Power-to-Methane(P2M). The objective is to minimize operating costs while also achieving benefits such as reducing carbon emissions and increasing the utilization of renewable energy. Electrical-to-gas and electrolytic hydrogen production technologies aid in the expansion of renewable energy usage, diminishing dependence on conventional fossil fuels, and enabling two-way integration in comprehensive energy systems. Current research primarily focuses on a limited range of applications for hydrogen energy, such as hydrogen storage, fuel cells, and hydrogen methanation. However, it lacks a comprehensive analysis of important factors like hydrogen energy utilization, demand response, and ladder-type carbon tax. The diverse energy attributes of building energy systems have revolutionized conventional electrical demand response into comprehensive answers encompassing power, cooling, and heating requirements. Song et al. [13] examine the incorporation of demand response and energy interconnection in the design and size of a port energy hub, resulting in a substantial decrease in total planning expenses. Xiao et al. [14] uses robust optimization and stochastic optimization to handle source load uncertainty, and establishes a integrated demand response model using price elasticity coefficients and transferable cold and heat loads. Guo et al. [15] based on the coupling characteristics of heterogeneous energy flow in regional integrated energy system and the response potential of flexible load on the user side, the concept of demand response (DR) in electricity market is extended to cooling and heat in energy system. Li et al. [16] establishes a comprehensive demand response mechanism considering the fuzziness of human thermal comfort and building thermal inertia, and uses distributed robust optimization to handle source load uncertainty. Hence, demand response technology efficiently accomplishes the reduction of peak load, mitigation of load fluctuations, and a decrease in system energy costs. In existing research, only the impact of user participation in demand response on system operation economy is usually considered, ignoring user comfort. However, in today's people-oriented society, user living experience has become an indispensable factor in energy system scheduling. The field of uncertainty optimization has been thoroughly researched. Fang et al. [17] examine the effects of uncertainty in wind power and its correlation over space and time on the functioning of integrated electrical systems. They propose a model that incorporates mixed distribution robust chance constraints and interval optimization to improve system security and cost efficiency. Yang et al. [18] examine the economic and resilient aspects of microgrid operation by developing a robust optimization model to handle uncertainties in microgrid operation. By solving the robust adjustment parameters, one can achieve optimization of system resilience and decrease operating expenses. Liu et al. [19] presents a recommended bidding strategy for a microgrid in the day-ahead market. They develop a mathematical model that combines stochastic and robust optimization techniques to minimize the projected net costs. The robust optimization approach is used to control the imbalance power in real-time markets. Fan et al. [20] establish a comprehensive energy system consortium by implementing energy sharing and carbon transfer. They propose a two-stage distribution robust optimization model that relies on kernel density estimation and wasserstein metric. This model aims to effectively coordinate robustness, economics, environmental protection, and efficiency. Hence, robust optimization techniques efficiently alleviate the influence of uncertainty in renewable energy generation and load forecasting on IES optimization, hence improving the economic and reliability aspects of system operation. In existing research, most scholars only consider robust optimization in the capacity allocation process, without considering the impact of source load uncertainty on demand response and user comfort. In summary, existing scholars have conducted research on the optimization of the operation of BIES, but the consideration of research factors is not comprehensive enough, and there is no analysis of the comprehensive impact of hydrogen energy utilization, demand response, and ladder-type carbon tax on the system. In the process of user participation in demand response, only the economic efficiency of system operation is considered, ignoring the user's comfort experience. There is no analysis of the impact of source load uncertainty on user participation in demand response and user comfort. Therefore, this article proposes a low-carbon operation optimization method for BIES that takes into account source load uncertainty and user comfort. It comprehensively considers the impact of hydrogen energy comprehensive utilization, ladder-type carbon tax, demand response, user comfort, and robust optimization on system operation, analyzes the carbon reduction effect of hydrogen energy comprehensive utilization and ladder-type carbon tax, studies the impact of user participation in different demand responses on economy and comfort, analyzes the relationship between robust optimization coefficient and adjustable load, economy, and comfort of the system, and ultimately selects a suitable optimization scheduling scheme to effectively improve the economic, environmental, and comfort of system operation. 1.3 Contribution and organization This article makes the following main contributions: (1) Investigates the effects of hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells and tiered carbon taxes on the expenses and carbon emissions of a whole building energy system, assuming the presence of multiple hydrogen sources. (2) Examines the energy requirements for electricity, cooling, and heating in the building, creating a model of integrated demand response. This model encompasses the reducible electric load, transferable electric load, transferable heat load, and adjustable cooling load. In addition, it develops a paradigm for evaluating user comfort. By incorporating user comfort criteria into the optimization objectives of the building energy system, it modifies user engagement in demand response behavior, hence improving the overall energy experience for users. (3) Applies resilient optimization theory to account for uncertainty in user demand response. The study demonstrates that various robustness coefficients have an influence on user engagement in demand response behavior. Utilizing robust optimization to tackle uncertainties in source-load dynamics boosts the adaptability of the system, hence indirectly enhancing the overall satisfaction of users. The main structure of this article is as follows: Section 2 establishes a model of BIES incorporating hydrogen utilization modes. Section 3 establishes a model of integrated demand response. Section 4 establishes a model of user comfort evaluation. Section 5 establishes a model of ladder-type carbon tax. Section 6 establishes a robust optimization model of renewable energy generation and user load. Section 7 establishes a operation optimization model of BIES. Section 8 presents a case analysis using a large building energy system in the northern region as an example. Section 9 discusses the advantages and disadvantages of the optimization method used in this article. Section 10 provides the research conclusions. 2 The model of BIES 2.1 The model of system The paper presents models for building supply and demand energy equipment, as well as user loads, based on the characteristics of summer source-load in a large office building. The system employs the electric grid, photovoltaic (PV), wind turbine (WT), gas turbine (GT), hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell (HOFC), and electricity storage (ES) to provide electricity to customers. Electric chillers (EC), absorption chillers (AC), ground source heat pumps (GSHP), and cold storage (CS) systems all contribute to the provision of cooling energy. Heat recovery steam generators (HRSG), HOFC, gas boilers (GB), and heat storage (HS) are devices that provide equipment and users with thermal energy. The natural gas pipeline delivers gas to the gas turbine and gas boiler, whereas power-to-hydrogen (P2H) equipment and hydrogen storage tanks (HST) supply hydrogen. The HOFC has the capability to provide both electrical and thermal energy requirements concurrently. The combined cooling, heating and power system, consisting of GT, HRSG, and AC, can efficiently provide electrical, cooling, and thermal energy simultaneously. The system employs ES, CS, HS, and HST to effectively manage and enhance power variations throughout operation, resulting in the reduction of peak power demand and the filling of low-demand periods (Fig. 1 ). 2.2 The model of equipment 2.2.1 PV The output power of photovoltaic equipment is primarily correlated with environmental temperature, light intensity, illuminated area, and other factors [21]. The power model of PV is shown in Equation (1). (1) P pv ( t ) = η pv ( t ) S G ac [ 1 + k 0 ( T c ( t ) − T r ) ] where P pv ( t ) represents the power generation of photovoltaic modules during the period t. η pv ( t ) is the average photoelectric conversion efficiency of the photovoltaic modules during the period t. S is the illuminated area of the solar panels. G ac ( t ) is the average light intensity on the photovoltaic modules during the period t. T c ( t ) is the average temperature of the photovoltaic modules during the period t. T ot is the minimum operating temperature of the photovoltaic modules. k 0 is the temperature coefficient of the photovoltaic modules. 2.2.2 WT WT is a power generation method that converts the kinetic energy of the wind into mechanical energy, and then converts mechanical energy into electrical energy. The power output of a fan is mainly related to wind speed, and when the wind speed is greater than the cut-out wind speed or less than the cut-out wind speed, the fan does not work [22]. The power model of WT is shown in Equation (2). (2) P wt ( t ) = { 0 , v ( t ) ≤ v c i P r v ( t ) − v c i v c o − v c i , v c i < v ( t ) ≤ v r P r , v r < v ( t ) ≤ v c o 0 , v c o < v ( t ) where P wt ( t ) represents the output electrical power of WT during the period t. v ( t ) is the real-time wind speed. v c i is the cut-in wind speed. v c o is the cut-out wind speed. v r is the rated wind speed of WT. P r is the rated power of WT. 2.2.3 P2H P2H converts electrical energy into hydrogen, which can be further utilized either by direct conversion through HOFC into electrical or thermal energy. Additionally, the produced hydrogen can be stored in HST or supplied directly to end-users [23]. The power model of P2H is shown in Equation (3). (3) W p 2 h ( t ) = P p 2 h ( t ) η p 2 h κ h where W p 2 h ( t ) is the mass of hydrogen gas output by P2H during time period t. P p 2 h ( t ) denotes the electrical power input by P2H during time period t. η p 2 h represents the energy conversion efficiency of P2H. κ h is the conversion factor between hydrogen mass and energy, taken as 39.54 kWh/kg. 2.2.4 HOFC As a crucial energy coupling device in integrated energy systems, HOFC facilitate the conversion between hydrogen energy and electrical or thermal energy. Due to the clean and non-polluting nature of hydrogen energy, coupled with its high conversion efficiency, HOFC holds significant advantages in enhancing the environmental sustainability of the system [23]. The power model of HOFC is represented by Equation (4). (4) { P hofc ( t ) = W hofc ( t ) κ h η fce H hofc ( t ) = W hofc ( t ) κ h η fch where W p 2 h ( t ) represents the mass of hydrogen input to the HOFC during the period t, while P hofc ( t ) and H hofc ( t ) denote the electrical and thermal power output of the HOFC during the period t. η fce and η fch respectively denote the electrical and thermal power conversion efficiencies of the HOFC. 2.2.5 GT GT is highly efficient, clean, and reliable energy conversion device that enable the efficient utilization and conversion of energy. They have the capability to supply both electrical and thermal energy, making them versatile in various applications. Gas turbines are widely utilized in the construction industry due to their effectiveness in energy conversion and dual energy supply capabilities [24]. The power model of HOFC is represented by Equation (5). (5) { P gt ( t ) = V gt ( t ) κ g η gte H gt ( t ) = V gt ( t ) κ g η gth where P gt ( t ) represents the electrical power output of GT during the period t. V gt ( t ) denotes the natural gas consumption of GT during the period t. κ g is the conversion factor between natural gas and energy, taken as 9.7 kWh/m3. η gte and η gth represent the electrical and thermal efficiencies of GT during the period t. H gt ( t ) is the thermal power output of GT during the period t. 2.2.6 HRSG HRSG have the capability to recover waste heat generated during industrial production processes and convert it into thermal energy such as steam or hot water. This process achieves energy conservation, emission reduction, and a reduction in energy costs. In this article, waste heat from both GT and HOFC can be recovered through HRSG, contributing to the overall efficiency and sustainability of the energy system [24]. The power model of HRSG is represented by Equation (6). (6) H hrsg ( t ) = ( H hofc ( t ) + H gt ( t ) ) η hrsg where H hrsg ( t ) represents the thermal power output of HRSG during the period t. η hrsg denotes the waste heat recovery efficiency of the HRSG during the period t. 2.2.7 AC AC powered by thermal energy offer the advantage of not requiring significant electrical energy consumption. Moreover, they have relatively low requirements for the quality of thermal energy, making them capable of efficiently utilizing high-grade thermal energy produced by HRSG for refrigeration purposes. This results in lower operational costs for the system [24]. The power model of AC is represented by Equation (7). (7) C ac ( t ) = H hrsg ( t ) φ eh ( t ) η ac where C ac ( t ) represents the cooling power output of AC during the period t. φ e h ( t ) denotes the proportion of waste heat from the HRSG consumed by AC during the period t. η ac represents the cooling efficiency of AC. 2.2.8 EC EC is a type of apparatus that utilizes electrical energy as a power source. It achieves the cooling effect on specific spaces or objects by circulating and regulating the flow of refrigerants. Widely employed in residential, commercial, and industrial sectors, it ensures people a comfortable ambient temperature [25]. The power model of EC is represented by Equation (8). (8) C ec ( t ) = P ec ( t ) η ec where C ec ( t ) represents the cooling power output of EC during the period t. P ec ( t ) denotes the electrical power consumption of EC during the period t. η ec is the cooling efficiency of EC. 2.2.9 GB GB is a device that utilizes the thermal energy generated by gas combustion to heat water or other working fluids into steam or hot water. Widely employed in industrial, commercial, and residential sectors, it is a common heating appliance [26]. The power model of GB is represented by Equation (9). (9) H gb ( t ) = V gb ( t ) κ g η gb where H gb ( t ) represents the heating power output of GB during the period t. V gb ( t ) denotes the natural gas consumption of GB during the period t. η gb is the gas-to-thermal energy conversion efficiency of GB. 2.2.10 GSHP GSHP is a device that utilizes geothermal energy stored in the ground for space heating and cooling. Due to its use of geothermal energy, it is generally considered an environmentally friendly and energy-efficient heating and cooling system [27]. The power model of GSHP is represented by Equation (10). (10) C gshp ( t ) = P gshp ( t ) η gshp where C gshp ( t ) represents the cooling power output of GSHP during the period t. P gshp ( t ) denotes the electrical power consumption of GSHP during the period t. η gshp is the cooling efficiency of GSHP. 2.2.11 ES/CS/HS/HST In this document, the models for electrical, cooling, heating, and hydrogen storage are similar, and a unified energy storage model is used to represent them [28]. The power model of energy storage devices is given by Equation (11). (11) S i ( t ) = S i ( t − 1 ) ( 1 − σ slc i , i ) + ( S cha , i ( t ) η cha , i − S dis , i ( t ) η dis , i ) where S i ( t ) and S i ( t − 1 ) respectively represent the stored energy of the i − th energy storage device during the period t and the period t − 1 . σ slc i signifies the self-discharge rate of the i − th energy storage device, where i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 can represent electrical, cooling, heating, or hydrogen energy storage devices. S cha , i ( t ) and S dis , i ( t ) represent the charging and discharging power of the i − th energy storage device during the period t. η cha and η dis respectively denote the charging and discharging efficiencies of the i-th energy storage device. 3 The model of IDR According to the type of user load and its response characteristics, user participation in demand response behavior can be classified into four categories: 1) Interruptible electrical load (IPL), where users can partially or completely reduce their electricity demand based on supply-demand conditions; 2) Transferable electrical load (TPL), referring to loads where the total electricity consumption remains constant during the scheduling period, but the electricity consumption in each time period can fluctuate within a certain range; 3) Transferable thermal load (THL), where the total heat requirement remains constant during the scheduling period, but the heat consumption in each time period can fluctuate within a certain range; 4) Adjustable cooling load (ACL), indicating the reduction of cooling load within the acceptable comfort range by leveraging the building's inherent cooling and heat storage characteristics. 3.1 IPL IPL primarily refers to the electrical load that can be reduced during specific time intervals [29]. This can have a certain impact on the energy consumption behavior of users within a building. However, simultaneously, it contributes to the overall reduction of the electrical power load during those specific time periods. The model can be obtained through Equation (12): (12) { 0 ≤ P cut ( t ) ≤ P cutmax ( t ) t ∈ T cut where P cut ( t ) represents the reduction in electrical load during the period. P cutmax ( t ) denotes the maximum possible reduction in electrical load during the period. T cut represents the time period range during which the electrical load can be reduced. 3.2 TPL BIES can guide users to TPL with transferable characteristics from peak load periods to off-peak load periods by providing compensation [30]. The model can be obtained through Equation (13): (13) { 0 ≤ P inc ( t ) ≤ σ e P incmax ( t ) , t ∈ T einc 0 ≤ P red ( t ) ≤ ( 1 − σ e ) P redmax ( t ) , t ∈ T ered ∑ P inc ( t ) = ∑ P red ( t ) where P inc ( t ) and P red ( t ) represent the electrical load increased and decreased by the user during the period respectively. P incmax ( t ) and P redmax ( t ) represent the maximum electrical load that users can increase or decrease during time period t. σ e is the user transferable electrical load identifier. When σ e = 1 , it indicates an increase in electrical load, and when σ e = 0 , it indicates a decrease in electrical load. T einc and T ered represent the time periods during which the user's electrical load can be increased or decreased, respectively. 3.3 THL THL requires ensuring that the total power demand for thermal load remains unchanged throughout the operational cycle. However, it does not have constraints on continuity and time series. It offers high operational flexibility within acceptable transfer time intervals. The model can be obtained through Equation (14): (14) { 0 ≤ H inc ( t ) ≤ σ h H incmax ( t ) , t ∈ T hinc 0 ≤ H red ( t ) ≤ ( 1 − σ h ) H redmax ( t ) , t ∈ T hred ∑ H inc ( t ) = ∑ H red ( t ) where H inc ( t ) and H red ( t ) represent the thermal load increased and decreased by the user during the period respectively. H incmax ( t ) and H redmax ( t ) represent the maximum thermal load that users can increase or decrease during time period t. σ h is the user transferable thermal load identifier. When σ h = 1 , it indicates an increase in electrical load, and when σ h = 0 , it indicates a decrease in thermal load. T hinc and T hred represent the time periods during which the user's thermal load can be increased or decreased, respectively. 3.4 ACL User perception of temperature comfort exhibits a degree of fuzziness, and adjusting indoor temperatures within a certain range will not significantly impact the user experience [31]. Leveraging this characteristic can enhance the regulation capability of cooling loads. Additionally, there is thermal inertia in cooling systems, and terminal heat perception has a time delay [32]. Therefore, optimizing the adjustment parameters of the cooling system can improve the overall load regulation capability of the building's integrated energy system. The model can be obtained through Equation (15): (15) { Q before ( t ) = T w ( t ) − T nb ( t ) − [ T w ( t ) − T n ( t − 1 ) ] × e γ R ( 1 − e γ ) Q after ( t ) = T w ( t ) − T nm ( t ) − [ T w ( t ) − T n ( t − 1 ) ] × e γ R ( 1 − e γ ) γ = − Δ t R C Q adjmax ( t ) = Q before ( t ) − Q after ( t ) , t ∈ T adj 0 ≤ Q adj ( t ) ≤ Q adjmax ( t ) , t ∈ T adj where Q before and Q after respectively represent the cooling load before and after the user participates in demand response during the period t. T w ( t ) is the outdoor temperature during the period t. T nb ( t ) is the initial set indoor temperature during the period t. T nm ( t ) is the minimum set indoor temperature during the period t. T n ( t − 1 ) is the indoor temperature during the period t. γ represents the building regulation parameter. R and C represent the equivalent thermal resistance and equivalent thermal capacitance of the interior of the building in the cooling system, respectively. Δt is the time interval, assumed to be 1 hour in this case. Q adjmax ( t ) represents the maximum adjustable value of the cooling load during the period t. Q adj ( t ) is the adjusted value of the cooling load during the period t. T adj represents the period during which the user's cooling load can be adjusted. 4 The model of user comfort The operation of demand response mechanisms, accompanied by changes in user energy consumption habits, is bound to impact users' daily lives. In response to this, the satisfaction of users with demand response is evaluated based on their comfort. The comfort models established in this study include electrical comfort, thermal comfort, and cooling comfort. 4.1 The electrical comfort The electrical comfort of users can be expressed as the ratio of interruptible electrical load and transferable electrical load participating in scheduling during each time period to the total electrical load. The model can be obtained through Equation (16): (16) L e = ∑ ( P cut ( t ) + P inc ( t ) + P red ( t ) ) P load ( t ) where L e represents the electrical comfort of the user. 4.2 The thermal comfort The thermal comfort of users can be expressed as the ratio of transferable thermal load participating in scheduling during each time period to the total thermal load. The model can be obtained through Equation (17): (17) L h = ∑ ( H inc ( t ) + H red ( t ) ) H load ( t ) where L h represents the thermal comfort of the user. 4.3 The cooling comfort Users exhibit a certain degree of fuzziness in their perception of changes in the surrounding environmental temperature. Fixed cooling loads can be transformed into cooling load intervals, effectively reducing energy waste. Predicted mean vote (PMV) is a comfort evaluation index based on building physics and psychophysiology, commonly used to assess whether the indoor thermal environment is comfortable [33]. The relationship between indoor temperature and the PMV index is expressed as Equation (18): (18) λ PMV = [ 0.303 × exp ⁡ ( − 0.036 M ) + 0.0275 ] × { M − W − 3.05 [ 5.733 − 0.007 ( M − W ) − P re ] − 0.42 ( M − W − 58.15 ) − 1.73 × 10 − 2 × M ( 5.867 − P re ) − 0.0014 M ( 34 − T n ) − 3.96 × 10 − 8 × f cl [ ( T cl + 273 ) 4 − ( t r + 273 ) 4 ] − f d h c ( T cl − T n ) } where λ PMV represents the PMV value. M and W respectively denote the metabolic rate and mechanical power produced by the human body. f cl is the ratio of the clothing-covered area to the exposed area of the body. h c is the surface heat transfer coefficient. P re is the indoor air pressure. t r and t cl are the average radiant temperature and the surface temperature of the clothing, respectively. In this article, users are assumed to participate in cooling load demand response during working hours from 9 am to 5 pm. Therefore, the ratio of the total PMV value after participating in cooling load demand response during working hours to the initial total PMV value of the cooling load is used as the comfort index for user participation in cooling load demand response. The model can be obtained through Equation (19): (19) L c = ∑ λ after ( t ) ∑ λ before ( t ) , t ∈ T adj where L c represents the cooling comfort of the user. In the equation, λ before ( t ) and λ after ( t ) respectively represent the comfort levels of the user before and after participating in cooling load demand response. 5 The model of ladder-type carbon tax The ladder-type carbon tax refers to a system where different tax rates are set based on different intervals of carbon emissions, typically with higher emissions incurring higher tax rates. The design of this taxation system aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through economic incentives, thereby mitigating the impact of global climate change [34]. The tiered carbon tax can encourage businesses and individuals to reduce energy consumption, fostering a shift towards more environmentally friendly production and consumption patterns. The model can be obtained through Equation (20): (20) D co 2 ( t ) = ∑ t = 1 24 P grid ( t ) ρ grid + ∑ t = 1 24 V gas ( t ) ρ gas + ∑ t = 1 24 W buy ( t ) ρ h 2 where P grid ( t ) represents the purchased electrical power of the system during the period t. V gas ( t ) represents the purchased gas quantity of the system during the period t. and W buy ( t ) represents the purchased hydrogen quantity of the system during the period t. ρ grid , ρ gas , and ρ h 2 are the carbon emission coefficients of electricity, gas, and hydrogen, respectively. The model of ladder-type carbon tax can be obtained through Equation (21): (21) C co 2 ( t ) = { C base D co2 ( t ) ⩽ l C base ( 1 + α ) l ⩽ D co2 ( t ) ⩽ 2 l C base ( 1 + 2 α ) 2 l ⩽ D co2 ( t ) ⩽ 3 l C base ( 1 + 3 α ) 3 l ⩽ D co2 ( t ) ⩽ 4 l C base ( 1 + 4 α ) D co2 ( t ) ⩾ 4 l where C co 2 ( t ) represents the carbon tax during the period t. C base is the base carbon trading price. l is the length of the carbon emission interval. α is the price growth rate. 6 The handle of system uncertainty Robust optimization is employed in the optimization process of system operation to handle uncertainties in photovoltaic, wind power generation, and user electrical loads. The stochastic variable b m n fluctuate within a certain range. The model can be obtained through Equation (22): (22) { b m n ∈ [ b ˜ m n − b ˆ m n , b ˜ m n + b ˆ m n ] b ˆ m n = μ ( b ¯ m n − b _ m n ) where b ¯ m n and b _ m n respectively represent the upper and lower bounds of the fluctuation of uncertain variables. μ is the fluctuation coefficient, and the range of the worst-case scenario for uncertain variables is b m n ∈ [ b _ m n , b ¯ m n ] . To avoid overly conservative decisions, a robust coefficient τ is introduced for control, where τ ∈ [ 0 , | ξ | ] . ξ represents the set of uncertain parameters within the system. With the introduction of τ, the fluctuation range of uncertain variables becomes b m n ∈ [ b ˜ m n − τ b ˆ m n , b ˜ m n + τ b ˆ m n ] . This article primarily addresses the uncertainty in the prediction of photovoltaic, wind power generation, electrical load, and cooling load. The model can be obtained through Equation (23): (23) { R i ( t ) + τ i ω i ( t ) + ξ i ≤ μ i ( R i + R _ i ) ω i + ξ i ≥ μ i ( R ¯ i + R _ i ) δ i ω i , ξ i ≥ 0 δ i ≥ 1 where ω i , ξ i , and δ i represent the calculation of auxiliary variables, and when i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , it denotes photovoltaic, wind power, electrical load, and cooling load, respectively. In this article, τ i represents the degree of robustness, adjusting for uncertainty, with values ranging from 0 to 24 as integers. Taking τ pv as an example, a larger τ pv implies greater uncertainty in photovoltaic power generation, corresponding to a “worse” scenario, making the optimization results more conservative. Conversely, a smaller τ pv concentrates the fluctuation range of photovoltaic power generation around the mean, reducing uncertainty, and making the optimization results more adventurous. When τ pv = 0 , it transforms into a mean deterministic model. Robust optimization allows for addressing all possible scenarios within the defined range, satisfying constraints under different scenarios, and finding the optimal system dispatch results based on the worst-case scenario. 7 Objective function and constraints 7.1 Objective function The operational costs of BIES mainly encompass energy purchase expenses, equipment maintenance costs, carbon tax expenses, demand response subsidies, and penalties for user comfort. The model of operational costs can be obtained through Equation (24): (24) F cost = F 1 + F 2 + F 3 + F 4 + F 5 1) The cost of energy purchase can be obtained through Equation (25): (25) F 1 = ∑ i = 1 24 P grid ( t ) × C grid ( t ) + ∑ i = 1 24 V gas ( t ) × C gas ( t ) + ∑ i = 1 24 W buy ( t ) × C h 2 ( t ) where C grid ( t ) , C gas ( t ) , and C h 2 ( t ) represent the electricity, gas, and hydrogen price during the period, respectively. 2) The cost of equipment maintenance can be obtained through Equation (26): (26) F 2 = ∑ i = 1 n ∑ t = 1 24 P i ( t ) ϕ i Δ t where P i ( t ) represents the output power of the i − t h type of equipment during the period t. ϕ i represents the maintenance cost per unit output of the i − t h type of equipment. 3) The cost of carbon tax can be obtained through Equation (27): (27) F 3 = D co 2 ( t ) C co 2 ( t ) 4) The subsidies of demand response can be obtained through Equation (28): (28) F 4 = ∑ i = 1 n ∑ t = 1 24 P a d i ( t ) Δ t C p i + ∑ i = 1 n ∑ t = 1 24 H a d i ( t ) Δ t C h i + ∑ i = 1 n ∑ t = 1 24 Q a d i ( t ) Δ t C p i where P a d i ( t ) , H a d i ( t ) , and Q a d i ( t ) represent the adjustment amounts for user electrical, thermal, and cooling loads, respectively, indicates the form of load adjustment. C p i , C h i , and C c i represents the subsidy price for different demand response. 5) The penalties of user comfort can be obtained through Equation (29): (29) F 5 = ( 1 − ϖ e L e + ϖ h L h + ϖ c L c ) θ where ϖ e , ϖ h , and ϖ c represent the weights for user electrical, thermal, and cooling comfort, determined using the entropy weight method, represents the penalty parameter for user comfort. 7.2 Constraints 1) The constraints of power balance are shown in Equation (30): (30) { P pv ( t ) + P wt ( t ) + P gt ( t ) + P hofc ( t ) + S 1 ( t ) + P grid ( t ) = P load ( t ) + P ec ( t ) + P gshp ( t ) + P gshp ( t ) + P p 2 h ( t ) − P cut ( t ) + P inc ( t ) − P red ( t ) H gb ( t ) + H hrsg ( t ) + S 2 ( t ) = H load ( t ) + H inc ( t ) − H red ( t ) Q ac ( t ) + Q ec ( t ) + Q gshp ( t ) + S 3 ( t ) = Q load ( t ) − Q adj ( t ) V gas ( t ) = V gt ( t ) + V gb ( t ) W p 2 h ( t ) + W buy ( t ) + S 4 ( t ) = W load ( t ) + W hofc ( t ) 2) The constraints of interconnection pipeline are shown in Equation (31): (31) { 0 ≤ P grid ( t ) ≤ P gridmax 0 ≤ V gas ( t ) ≤ V gasmax 0 ≤ W buy ( t ) ≤ W buymax where P gridmax , V gasmax , and W buymax are the upper limits for system electricity purchase, gas purchase, and hydrogen purchase, respectively. 3) The constraints of equipment operation are shown in Equation (32): (32) { 0 ≤ P i ( t ) ≤ P i max 0 ≤ H i ( t ) ≤ H i max 0 ≤ Q i ( t ) ≤ Q i max where P i ( t ) ≤ P i max , H i ( t ) ≤ H i max , and Q i ( t ) ≤ Q i max represent the output upper limits for the i − t h type of power generation, heating, and cooling equipment, respectively. 4) The constraints of energy storage are shown in Equation (33): (33) { S i min ≤ S i ( t ) ≤ S i max 0 ≤ S i in ( t ) ≤ S i inmax X i 0 ≤ S i out ( t ) ≤ S i outmax Y i X i + Y i ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) S i ( 0 ) = S i ( 24 ) where S i min and S i max are the upper and lower limits for the state of charge (SOC) of energy storage devices. S i inmax and S i outmax are the maximum charging and discharging power for energy storage devices. X i and Y i represent the charge or discharge state variable for energy storage. S i ( 0 ) and S i ( 24 ) are the initial and final SOC of energy storage devices within the scheduling period, where i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 denote energy storage devices for electricity, heating, cooling, and hydrogen. 7.3 Solution methods The solution algorithm in this study mainly involves two aspects. Firstly, the establishment of the demand response evaluation system requires determining the weights of various evaluation indicators. Secondly, the operational optimization model for BIES, established in this paper, belongs to a mixed-integer nonlinear programming process that cannot be directly solved. Therefore, a combined approach of GA-CPLEX is employed for computation. 7.3.1 Weight allocation In this study, the entropy weight method is employed to determine the weights of evaluation indicators for the demand response results of the comprehensive energy system. The entropy weight method is an approach used for multi-index comprehensive evaluation. It relies on the concept of information entropy to determine the importance of indicators and assign corresponding weights [35]. Information entropy is typically used to measure the disorder or uncertainty of data. The calculation process is as follows: Step 1: First, normalize each indicator. Assuming the paper provides m evaluation schemes { X 1 , X 2 , . . . , X m } for various scenarios, each scheme includes n evaluation indicators X i = { x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n } . Let { Y 1 , Y 2 , . . . , Y m } represent the normalized value of the j − t h indicator in the i − t h scheme. The process of solving evaluation indicators is shown in Equation (34) and Equation (35): (34) X i j = X i j − min ⁡ ( X i ) max ⁡ ( X i ) − min ⁡ ( X i ) (Positive indicators) (35) X i j = max ⁡ ( X i ) − X i j max ⁡ ( X i ) − min ⁡ ( X i ) (Negative indicators) Step 2: Calculate the ratio of each indicator in each scheme, i.e., the proportion of the j − t h indicator in the i − t h scheme relative to that indicator. This step aims to assess the magnitude of variation for each indicator. The solving process is shown in Equation (36): (36) P i j = Y i j ∑ i = 1 m Y i j ( i = 1 , 2 , … , m ; j = 1 , 2 , … , n ) Step 3: Calculate the information entropy for each indicator. According to the definition of information entropy in information theory, the information entropy of a set of data can be solved by Equation (37): (37) E j = − ln ⁡ ( n ) − 1 ∑ i = 1 m P i j ln ⁡ P i j where 0 ≤ E j , if P i j = 0 , E j = 0 . Step 4: Determine the weights of each indicator. Based on the calculated information entropy for each indicator { E 1 , E 2 , . . . , E m } , the weight determination process is shown in Equation (38): (38) W j = 1 − E j n − ∑ i = 1 n E j ( j = 1 , 2 , … , n ) After the calculation, the weights for the comfort of electricity supply, heating, and cooling are determined to be 0.3989, 0.1123, and 0.4888, respectively. 7.3.2 The algorithm of operational optimization This article takes user participation in demand response behavior as a decision variable and considers user comfort into the system optimization objectives. In the process of calculating demand response penalties, it is necessary to first calculate the indoor temperature changes based on the numerical values of user participation in various demand responses, then calculate PMV based on indoor temperature, and finally obtain user comfort and penalties. CPLEX can only use the constraints function to match the source load balance conditions based on the load range of user participation in demand response, and cannot directly obtain the numerical value of user participation in demand response during the process. It is impossible to calculate the user comfort penalty during the programming process, which can lead to errors in the solution process. Therefore, in essence, the calculation process of comfort penalty in economic goals is an undetermined constraint problem, CPLEX cannot be directly solved. Heuristic algorithms, on the other hand, group and simultaneously calculate the fitness of all possible results within a variable range, and then compare the quality of the results. During the calculation process, they can obtain the exact value of user participation in demand response, which can be used to handle the problem of demand response penalty calculation, which is an undetermined constraint. Traditional genetic algorithms (GA) have problems such as slow convergence speed and susceptibility to getting stuck in local optima, and the results obtained may not be the global optimal solution [36]. Genetic algorithms use penalty functions to handle energy balance constraints. When the penalty function parameters are too large or too small, it can easily affect the accuracy of the final results. But the algorithm can handle the undetermined constraints in the model through preset parameters, which can help solve the problem of comfort penalty calculation. CPLEX has fast computation speed and unique solution results, but cannot handle undetermined constraints. Therefore, this article adopts the calculation method of GA-PLEX for solving, and the specific framework is shown in the Fig. 2 . 8 Case study 8.1 Basis data To illustrate the performance of the model in this study, empirical research was conducted using a typical summer energy use scenario in a large office building in northern China. Fig. 3 presents WT and PV forecast data for a typical day of 24 hours in the summer, along with the predicted user loads for electricity, cooling, heating, and hydrogen. The left y-axis represents the predicted range of WT, PV, and electrical, cooling, and thermal load power in kW, while the right y-axis represents the predicted range of hydrogen load mass in kg. The scheduling duration was set for 24 hours, with a unit scheduling time of 1 hour. The building participated in demand response for electricity and heating loads throughout the entire period, and engaged in demand response for cooling loads during working hours (9-17 hours). This article refers to Ref. [37] to set system optimization related parameters. Table 2 provides the equipment operating parameters, Table 3 provides the equipment maintenance costs, Table 4 provides relevant parameters of energy storage devices, Table 5 provides PMV parameters, Table 6 provides energy price-related parameters. Other parameters are listed in Table 7 . The parameter of user comfort penalty was set to 40000, with a genetic algorithm population size of 100 and 50 iterations. 8.2 Case description This study established six scenarios to compare and analyze the effectiveness of the proposed method. The scenarios mainly considered whether to incorporate comprehensive hydrogen utilization (CHU), whether to consider ladder-type carbon tax (LTCT), participation in IDR, consideration of user comfort (UC), and accounting for source-load uncertainty (SCU). Table 8 provides an overview of these scenarios. 8.3 Case simulation results and discussion Scenarios 1 to 5 do not consider the impact of source-load uncertainty; therefore, the obtained results can be considered deterministic. Hence, a unified comparison is conducted for these scenarios. Scenario 6 introduces the influence of the robustness coefficient, and when τ = 0 , scenario 6 can be regarded as scenario 5. Therefore, the operational results for scenario 6 under τ = 0 , 6 , 12 , 18 , 24 are compared separately. Taking scenario 5 as an example, Fig. 4 shows the calculation iteration process of GA-CPLEX, and sets different genetic algorithm parameters for comparison. The results show that convergence is achieved around 50 generations when the genetic population is 100. As the population increases, the number of iterations required for convergence decreases. However, as shown in Table 9 , as the population size increases, the system's solving time also increases. When the population is too small, the system is prone to falling into local optima. Therefore, this article selects a population size of 100 and an iteration number of 50 for the genetic algorithm. The user comfort penalty parameter is the parameter that evaluates the quality of user comfort in the objective function. In this paper, different penalty parameters were tested during the experiment, and the comfort penalty parameter was ultimately selected as 40000. 8.3.1 The analysis of hydrogen comprehensive utilization In scenario 1 and scenario 2, after incorporating HOFC into BIES, the most significant changes in power are observed in the power supply equipment and hydrogen production equipment. Therefore, this section focuses on analyzing the power balance for electricity and hydrogen in scenario 1 and scenario 2. It can be seen in Figs. 5–8 , the user's building is involved in PV and WT. WT exhibits off-peak characteristics, generating a significant amount during the low load periods of 1-5 h and 23-24 h, which may lead to curtailment. Therefore, during these periods, P2H outputs a large amount, converting excess wind power into hydrogen for storage. When there is a demand for useful hydrogen, it is supplied from storage, and any shortfall in hydrogen demand is supplemented by purchasing gray hydrogen from external sources. This strategy enhances the system's renewable energy integration rate. Additionally, during this low-cost energy period, GT simultaneously provides both electricity and heat, meeting the demands of other electrical devices. During peak electricity demand periods, although energy prices rise, GT continues to operate at full capacity due to its electric-thermal coupling advantage, supplying a significant amount of electrical energy. The HOFC, with its high energy conversion efficiency and environmentally friendly operation, replaces some of the GT's power during peak electricity demand periods, meeting the user's energy needs. Throughout the entire optimization period, as the electricity purchasing price from the grid is high and the total power output of all supplying devices exceeds the user's load demand, the system does not purchase electricity from the grid. Tables 10 and 11 indicate that, in scenario 2, due to the lower carbon emission factor of gray hydrogen and the high energy conversion efficiency of the HOFC, the system reduces the purchase of natural gas while increasing the purchase of gray hydrogen to supply the HOFC. As a result, the overall operating cost decreases by 0.39%, and carbon emissions are reduced by 3.97%. Although the economic improvement is not substantial, it contributes to a reduction in the overall carbon footprint of the system, aligning with the development philosophy of dual carbon goals. With the further maturity of electrolytic hydrogen production technology and fuel cells, it is expected that the economic and environmental performance of the system will be further enhanced. 8.3.2 The analysis of ladder-type carbon tax Tables 10 and 11 indicate that considering the stepped carbon tax, due to the higher carbon emission factors of purchased electricity and gas, which could result in an increased carbon tax, the system tends to reduce the purchase of natural gas and increase the purchase of gray hydrogen. The purchase of natural gas decreases by 13.1%, while the purchase of gray hydrogen increases by 42.78%. The advantages of HOFC, with high energy conversion efficiency and low carbon emissions, are fully utilized. As shown in Fig. 9, 10 , the system procures a substantial amount of gray hydrogen during periods of high energy demand, meeting the energy demand of the HOFC. During peak gas prices, the proportion of energy supplied by HOFC significantly increases, reducing the output power of GT, and consequently, reducing carbon emissions caused by natural gas conversion. This results in a 6.76% reduction in system carbon emissions. With the entire building sector accounting for 30% of total societal energy consumption in China, addressing the significant carbon reduction gap requires comprehensive consideration of various emission reduction measures to meet the dual carbon goals promptly. 8.3.3 The analysis of IDR As shown in Fig. 11, 12, 13 , after adjusting their energy consumption behavior through demand response subsidies, users achieve the most significant reduction in electrical load during the afternoon and evening peaks, with a maximum reduction of 589 kW, representing a decrease of 15.89%. Through adjustments in interruptible and transferable loads, the system better achieves peak shaving and valley filling, effectively reducing peak-to-valley differences, smoothing load fluctuations, and contributing to the stability of the power network. After participating in demand response for heating loads, users, through the form of load transfer, shift the usage time for certain heating loads, making better use of the complementary characteristics of the building's comprehensive energy system. During periods of high electricity demand, both GT and HOFC operate at high power, generating a significant amount of waste heat. After conversion in a waste heat boiler, this heat can be directly supplied to users. By concentrating the use of heat during periods of high electricity demand, users reduce energy consumption in other periods, contributing to the overall economic improvement of the system and indirectly reducing system carbon emissions. Users almost fully participate in demand response during working hours (9 am to 5 pm), with an average reduction of around 20%. This indicates that users are willing to sacrifice some of their comfort to obtain more economic subsidies. The decrease in user demand for cooling significantly alleviates the concentrated energy demand of the system, reducing the peak-to-valley difference in loads and easing the ramp-up power of the equipment, thereby aiding the system's economically secure operation. From Tables 10 and 11, it is evident that after users participate in demand response, the system's operating costs decrease by 5.57%, and carbon emissions reduce by 12.29%. The system's economic performance is even better than when not considering the stair-step carbon tax prices. This indicates that when users have a strong willingness to participate in demand response, effective control over the user's peak-to-valley difference can be achieved. Simultaneously, during periods of high energy demand, the load is significantly reduced, decreasing the energy consumption associated with concentrated energy supply and lowering energy purchasing costs. This substantial improvement in environmental performance contributes to fostering energy-saving habits among users, promoting the transition of buildings towards green construction practices. 8.3.4 The analysis of user comfort From Fig. 14, 15, 16 , it can be observed that incorporating a comfort penalty into the system optimization objective does not affect the user's electricity load response. However, the user's thermal load usage period is more concentrated during the peak electricity load period, effectively utilizing the waste heat generated by the GT and HOFC during peak electricity demand. This highlights the multi-energy complementarity characteristics of the building's comprehensive energy system. When considering their own comfort, users selectively reduce some cooling demand during the peak cooling load period, rather than fully participating in demand response within the adjustable range based on subsidies. During the relatively high temperature period at 13/14 h, users reduce the cooling demand to the minimum, ensuring the user's comfort requirements during the summer heat, reflecting the design philosophy of putting people first in buildings and contributing to enhancing user work efficiency. From Fig. 17, 18 , it is evident that when users fully participate in cooling load demand response, the indoor temperature approaches 28°C, significantly deviating from the theoretical comfort temperature of 26°C. The PMV value is also approaching the comfort zone range required in China. Such an environment has a substantial impact on the user's office efficiency and is not conducive to the sustainable development of the building. However, when considering user comfort requirements in the system's optimization objectives, the user's maximum temperature is around 27°C, especially at the highest outdoor temperature at 13 h, with a lower temperature reduction, effectively ensuring the user's office comfort needs. According to Table 12 , utilizing the comfort objectives set in this study, a total comfort level of 1 indicates that users did not participate in any demand response, and the energy comfort level is at its highest. In Scenario 4, users participated extensively in various demand responses, resulting in a decrease in comfort by 11.39%, with a significant impact on cold comfort, decreasing by 15.77%. This greatly affects the user's work enthusiasm. After considering user comfort in the system's operational objectives, the overall operating cost of the system increased by 0.99%, while the comprehensive comfort level increased by 4.27%, and the cold comfort level increased by 8.53%. With minimal economic costs, a greater improvement in comfort is achieved, contributing to enhancing the working environment for users and increasing the sense of identity among building occupants. 8.3.5 The analysis of source-load uncertainty Fig. 19, 20, 21, 22 shows the predicted results for photovoltaic, wind power generation, electric load, and cooling load under different robust coefficients. From the figure, it can be observed that when the robust coefficient τ is small, the system's renewable energy generation and load predictions are more accurate with less fluctuation. When τ = 0 , the entire system is approximately determined by optimization. In this case, user demand response behavior has no margin, and when there is fluctuation in the prediction results, it is easy to exceed the user's load adjustment range, affecting the overall energy system's operational safety and user energy comfort. When the robust coefficient τ is large, the system's prediction results have greater volatility. In this case, considering robust optimization, the system will optimize scheduling based on the worst-case scenario, obtaining more conservative operational results. When the actual values of WT, PV, and load differ from the predicted values, there is also room for user load adjustment, enhancing the system's operational reliability. Table 13 indicates that as the robustness coefficient increases, the system fully considers the uncertainty of the source load, influencing the operational optimization and formulating operational scheduling strategies under the worst-case scenario. The total amount of interruptible electric load and adjustable electric load continuously increases. When, the total interruptable electrical load increases by 20.03%, and the total adjustable electric load increases by 19.99%, providing a significant amount of adjustable load resources for the system. This enhancement improves the system's ability to cope with extreme conditions and increases its anti-interference capability. Users participate in adjusting the interruptible electric load based on their needs and participate in adjusting the cooling load based on their comfort level. The total amount of transferable electric load and transferable thermal load is continually adjusted during the system optimization process, leading to a 2.76% improvement in overall comfort. From Fig. 23 , it is evident that when the system's robustness coefficient is too large, the system considers the worst-case scenario, supplying excessive cooling load to users. In this scenario, the real values of photovoltaic and wind power are smaller than predicted, while the actual values of electric and cooling loads are higher than predicted. This often results in providing users with an excess of cooling load, causing the indoor PMV value to be smaller. This provides users with a larger adjustable load range, and judicious load reduction can better meet users' comfort requirements. Fig. 24 shows that as the robustness coefficient increases, the user's electrical and thermal comfort remains relatively unchanged, while the cooling comfort continually improves. In hot summer conditions, the user's demand for cooling comfort plays a significant role in the overall comfort. The user's participation in the adjustable cooling load process significantly influences the overall comfort, leading to a continuous increase in overall comfort as the user's demand for cooling comfort rises. From Fig. 25 , it is observed that as the system's robustness coefficient increases, the system considers the worst-case scenario to supply energy to users, requiring the purchase of a large amount of energy to meet the specified requirements. Consequently, the system's economic cost increases. At the same time, the total adjustable load of the system is continually rising. However, since the actual scheduled load of the system is often less than the total adjustable load, the user's comfort is instead improved. In practical applications, it is necessary to consider both the system's operating costs and user comfort requirements. Choosing an appropriate robustness coefficient for optimizing the system scheduling is the focus of the subsequent research in this paper. 9 Discussion This article analyzes the impact of HOFC, ladder-type carbon tax, integrated demand response, user comfort, and source-load uncertainty on the optimization of BIES operation. It is found that the proposed method can effectively improve the economic and environmental efficiency of BIES operation, and also ensure the comfort of user energy consumption. Wang et al. [38] considers introducing P2H and HOFC into IES to analyze the promoting effect of hydrogen comprehensive utilization on energy conservation, carbon reduction, and new energy consumption, but does not consider the impact of adding a ladder-type carbon tax mechanism on IES carbon emissions. Based on the experimental results, it can be concluded that considering the comprehensive utilization of hydrogen energy and the ladder-type carbon tax, IES achieves a significant reduction in carbon emissions with lower economic costs, which is more in line with China's emission reduction policy requirements. Zhang et al. [39] considered the impact of integrated demand response mechanism and ladder-type carbon trading mechanism on IES carbon emissions and economy, but did not consider the impact of participating in demand response behavior on user energy habits. Frequent participation in demand response behavior can reduce user energy experience, affect user energy comfort, and in the long run, it is not conducive to the operation of IES and does not conform to the people-oriented architectural design concept. In this article, after BIES participated in demand response, the PMV value of users increased from 9-17 hours. However, considering user comfort, the overall growth rate was relatively small, closer to the comfort range specified in China, and the user's office experience was better. Compared with existing research methods, this article incorporates user comfort as a penalty factor into the optimization objectives of system operation, balancing the impact of participating in demand response on user comfort, and obtaining a better user comfort with lower economic costs, better demonstrating the practical concept of putting people first in green buildings. At the same time, this article considers the impact of source load uncertainty on user participation in the demand response process. Using robust optimization methods to handle source load uncertainty can effectively improve the total adjustable load of users, but the actual amount of user participation in demand response will not change too much, thereby indirectly improving user energy comfort. Fan et al. [40] proposes a new two-stage optimization scheduling model based on distributed robust adaptive model predictive control, which effectively improves the accuracy and efficiency of scheduling while considering the robustness and economy of IES. However, the impact of improving system robustness on user participation in demand response behavior was not considered. As shown in Table 10, as the robustness coefficient increases, the flexibility of user participation in demand response also increases with the increase of system adjustable margin. Meanwhile, the variation of adjustable load will have an impact on the user's energy comfort, and it is necessary to comprehensively consider the user's comfort, economy, and reliability requirements, and select appropriate robustness coefficients for optimization. However, there are still some shortcomings in this study. The penalty factor for user comfort during the optimization process of system operation is a fixed value, and in practical situations, users have different requirements for comfort at different time periods. Variable penalty factors should be considered, or a Pareto solution set should be obtained through multi-objective solving methods, and appropriate optimization results should be selected. In terms of source load uncertainty, this article only considers the impact of source load uncertainty on the system's participation in demand response. However, in practical situations, source load uncertainty will have a greater impact on the capacity of the system's energy supply equipment. Therefore, in the following research process, it is necessary to comprehensively consider the impact of source load uncertainty on system capacity configuration and participation in demand response. 10 Conclusion This paper proposes a method for optimizing the functioning of an energy system. The method takes into account uncertainties in energy sources and loads, as well as user comfort. It also incorporates the concept of HOFC into the building integrated energy system. This study examines the impact of HOFC on reducing carbon emissions in a system that involves several sources of hydrogen and varying levels of carbon levies. Afterwards, considering the adaptable features of electric, cooling, and heating loads in the building, a comprehensive demand response model and user comfort model are created. The study investigates how user engagement in various demand response activities affects both user comfort and system operation. Robust optimization techniques are used to address the influence of unknown source-load conditions on the system's involvement in demand response scheduling. Ultimately, the efficacy of the suggested model and approach is confirmed using instance simulation analysis. The results are summarized as follows: (1) This article considers the linkage between comprehensive utilization of hydrogen energy and a ladder-type carbon tax mechanism, aiming to improve the effectiveness of hydrogen energy utilization, reduce the overall carbon emissions of BIES by 6.76%, enhance the overall environmental protection of operation, and promote the achievement of the dual carbon goals. (2) By establishing a user comfort model and incorporating user comfort penalties into the system's operational objectives, users are guided to participate in demand response behavior. Compared with full user participation in demand response, the comprehensive comfort of the system has increased by 4.27%, and the cooling comfort has increased by 8.53%. With minimal economic cost, greater comfort improvement has been achieved, realizing the design concept of building people-oriented and ensuring the cooling needs of users for summer work. (3) This article uses robust optimization to address the uncertainty of source and load, resulting in a 20% increase in the total adjustable load of the system and a 2.76% increase in overall user comfort. It enhances the system's ability to cope with extreme environments, enhances its anti-interference ability, and ensures user energy comfort. In practical applications, typical source load scenarios can be obtained based on the historical source load data of the target building. The energy structure can be adjusted according to the energy equipment in the building, and the system parameters can be adjusted according to the actual application process. The research method proposed in this article can be used for simulation to obtain energy scheduling schemes with reference value. Each energy scheduling plan should be adjusted according to actual usage needs, and the results they obtain may not be exactly the same. We will continue to delve deeper into the research method proposed in this study, refine the parameter details, and ensure that it can have an impact on the actual energy scheduling process. As BIES advances and energy conversion efficiency in supply equipment improves, we see a future where user comfort and system operational costs are no longer contradictory goals. Our future research will focus on optimizing the scheduling of the system to address these problems. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen, being a clean energy source, presents novel possibilities for the efficient exploitation of building energy. Nevertheless, the unpredictability in the production of renewable energy, the fluctuating demand from users, and the varying comfort needs within buildings provide substantial obstacles to the functioning of building energy systems. This work suggests an optimal technique for managing a comprehensive energy system based on hydrogen. The strategy takes into account the variability in energy sources and the need for user satisfaction. Firstly, a model of building integrated energy system (BIES) is created, which includes devices for utilizing hydrogen due to its adaptable qualities. Afterwards, the adaptable attributes of electrical, cooling, and heating loads within the building are carefully examined, resulting in the creation of a integrated demand response (IDR) model and a user-integrated comfort rating model. Moreover, a ladder-type carbon tax framework is implemented, employing robust optimization methods to tackle uncertainty in the production of renewable energy and demand. Finally, a model for optimizing the scheduling of energy system operation is formulated. A case analysis is performed utilizing a spacious office building located in the northern region as an instructive example. The findings indicate that the suggested approaches successfully control user involvement in demand response, decrease carbon emissions in the system, improve user energy comfort, and accomplish the economic, low-carbon, and comfortable functioning of BIES.
